recipes.name: Blueberry Pie
recipes.memory: A memory surfaces as you eat. This was one of Grandma's favourite desserts. She would always serve it just before bed. It made us heavy-eyed and calm at night, yet somehow we always woke the next morning full of energy.

steps.player_text: From the pantry, combine flour, sugar, and eggs. Work the mixture together until it forms a soft dough, then press it gently into the pie dish.
Before anything else, zest the orange. Grandma always said the scent should be the first thing to fill the kitchen.
Scatter the blueberries into the prepared crust, letting them settle naturally.
Finish with a light sprinkle of wild thyme — just enough to hint at the forest without overpowering the fruit. Bake until golden and the kitchen fills with the scent of warm pie.

recipes.name: Herbal Tea
recipes.memory: As the tea settles, a familiar warning returns. Grandma often spoke of the forest and the secrets it held. Its bounties were plentiful, she said, but so were its dangers — and respect was the price of safely taking from it.

steps.player_text: Bring the water to a gentle boil in the old kettle. Wait for the familiar whistle that used to call you to the kitchen.
Add the fresh mint to the hot water. Its delicate leaves should still hold the morning dew, releasing their cool, refreshing scent.
Stir in the chamomile flowers, letting their gentle floral notes mingle with the mint.
Let everything steep together. Stir in honey until it dissolves, creating a warm, comforting blend.

recipes.name: Garlic Bread
recipes.memory: A familiar comfort follows the first bite. Garlic bread is not only delicious — it keeps those damned blood suckers away. Grandma never baked it without a reason.

steps.player_text: Mix the flour and water together, kneading until the dough becomes smooth and elastic. Let it rest, covered with a cloth, until it's ready to shape.
Finely chop the wild garlic. Its pungent aroma will fill the air, sharp and earthy — just as Grandma preferred it.
Add the wild thyme to the chopped garlic. The forest herb's earthy notes will complement the sharpness of the wild garlic.
Stir in the fresh parsley, chopping it fine enough to release its oils. The bright, fresh flavor will balance the stronger herbs.
Shape the dough into a rustic loaf, pressing the herb mixture into the surface. Bake until the crust is golden and the kitchen smells of warm bread and wild herbs.
